author: RedacciÃ³n BLU Radio
title: El monumento a Cristo Rey nuevamente estÃ¡ abierto al pÃºblico - BluRadio
text: Este viernes se reaperturÃ³ el monumento a Cristo Rey, tras haber permanecido cerrado para el pÃºblico alrededor de 16 meses, mientras se le adelantaba un proceso de restauraciÃ³n. Fueron 9.800 metros cuadrados intervenidos en la cima del cerro, para crear senderos y edificaciones que permitirÃ¡n que la visita de caleÃ±os y turistas sea mÃ¡s dinÃ¡mica. AquÃ­ hay tres edificaciones grandes: El edificio de bienvenida donde va a estar toda la informaciÃ³n turÃ­stica y las entidades ambientales. El edificio de Terrazas, con tres niveles, con un auditorio, una zona de cafeterÃ­a y un mirador 360. En el edificio monumento tendremos en la base la experiencia turÃ­stica, y el Cristo totalmente renovado El paso hacia el monumento tendrÃ¡ un horario restringido desde las 3:00 hasta las 6:00 de la tarde y los visitantes deberÃ¡n estar acompaÃ±ados de un guÃ­a turÃ­stico. "Explicar que vamos a empezar a hacer unas aperturas de manera progresiva, dado que aunque los edificios ya estÃ¡n terminados, la parte de senderos todavÃ­a estÃ¡ en terminaciÃ³n, en todo lo que son las plataformas elevadas", finalizÃ³ la secretaria. La remodelaciÃ³n del monumento hace parte del Proyecto Integral Cristo Rey, el cual busca conectar a travÃ©s de senderos, el sector de San Fernando, en la zona plana de Cali, con la cima del cerro Los Cristales, la culminaciÃ³n del resto del proyecto quedarÃ¡ en manos del prÃ³ximo alcalde, Alejandro Eder. author: Alexandre Borges
title: Uma escuridÃ£o que nunca se acende - Observador
text:
E veio o dia em que a luz se foi. Depressa, na minha ultra-rÃ¡pida cabeÃ§a contemporÃ¢nea, passei de achar que uma lÃ¢mpada tinha, simplesmente, fundido e trocado por outra que, raisparta, tambÃ©m nÃ£o funcionava, jÃ¡ depois de ter partido ainda outra pelo caminho e amaldiÃ§oado as manhÃ£s de segunda-feira, para a consciÃªncia de que o corte era generalizado e, enfim, chegado o apocalipse e como me arrependia de nÃ£o ter aproveitado e agradecido, devidamente, aquele tempo remoto em que o mundo era um sÃ­tio normal, sem pandemias, nem invasÃµes, nem catÃ¡strofes naturais todas as estaÃ§Ãµes, nem colapsos da rede energÃ©tica. Talvez vejamos demasiados filmes, mas de uma triste coisa, leitor, pode ter a certeza: Putin jÃ¡ ganhou. Nem precisa de se mexer para que todos o temam. NÃ£o precisa de sair de Moscovo para que vejamos a sua sombra em toda a parte, a puxar todos os cordelinhos ou a cortar os fios, consoante o apetite da manobra.
Como tantos outros passageiros desta ibÃ©rica jangada de pedra, reteve o escriba na retina deste histÃ³rico 28 de Abril a estranha facilidade com que se instala, no sÃ©culo XXI, a impressÃ£o do caos. Os paralelos com os dias da COVID foram imediatos, os semÃ¡foros apagados a transformarem o trÃ¢nsito de Lisboa (no caso) em Mumbai, como se jÃ¡ ninguÃ©m se lembrasse da regra da prioridade ou fosse assunto do grau de complexidade da mecÃ¢nica quÃ¢ntica. A corrida aos supermercados, outra vez, para levar todo o papel higiÃ©nico, garrafÃµes de Ã¡gua e latas de conserva do HemisfÃ©rio. As teorias sobre as causas a saÃ­rem mais rÃ¡pido que farturas quentes em dia de feira. A desconfortÃ¡vel sensaÃ§Ã£o da desconfianÃ§a nas instituiÃ§Ãµes, dos governos Ã s grandes empresas, e de que, portanto, a qualquer momento, isto tem de ser cada um por si e a Renova por todos.
Algo, porÃ©m, nÃ£o podia contrastar mais naquelas 11 horas de concentrado de fim do mundo em relaÃ§Ã£o ao Ãºltimo que tÃ­nhamos vivido, ainda hÃ¡ cinco curtÃ­ssimos anos: a falta de informaÃ§Ã£o. Se, atÃ© ver, nÃ£o havia agora por aÃ­ Ã  solta nenhum vÃ­rus mortal, nÃ£o tÃ­nhamos desta feita como ficar comodamente em casa, a ver Netflix e encomendar sushi pela Glovo, entre conferÃªncias de imprensa da Dra. GraÃ§a Freitas, memes nas redes e videochamadas para os amigos confinados, enquanto â€œelesâ€, alguÃ©m, mÃ©dicos ou electricistas, resolviam o assunto. Aqui pelo bairro, sem tv, internet, telefone e, Ã s tantas, sequer as milagrosas mensagens entre iPhones que ainda foram trazendo, nas primeiras horas, actualizaÃ§Ãµes do estado do apagÃ£o chegadas do Portugal insular onde a vida seguia luminosamente normal, instalou-se, aos poucos, a ansiedade. Quanto tempo demoraria? O que estaria a acontecer? E se os cogumelos super-desenvolvidos de â€œThe Last of Usâ€ jÃ¡ tivessem tomado conta de tudo, houvesse uma receita de veneno facilmente produzÃ­vel em casa e sÃ³ o cronista nÃ£o tivesse como a saber preparar?
ImpossÃ­vel concentrar-se no que quer que fosse, escrita, leitura, simples apanhar sol num dos cinco Ãºnicos dias de 2025 em que ele atÃ© agora apareceu; de modo que se pÃ´s a caminho do Observador â€“ se as notÃ­cias nÃ£o vÃ£o a um homem, vai um homem Ã s notÃ­cias. Ã€ saÃ­da, e devidamente informado de que em Abrantes, MaÃ§Ã£o ou Gaia se reacendia jÃ¡ a esperanÃ§a de que seria escuridÃ£o de pouca dura, adquiriu por modestos 9,95â‚¬ um pack rÃ¡dio+pilhas na loja do chinÃªs do outro lado da rua, Ãºnico outro estabelecimento aberto nas redondezas e ilustraÃ§Ã£o para crianÃ§as das razÃµes para o que distingue o estado da nossa economia da chinesa. A partir daÃ­, foi um suave deslizar informado atÃ© por volta das 20h40, precisamente quando a noite caÃ­a, se acendia as primeiras velas e comeÃ§ava a cozinhar a comida jÃ¡ semi-descongelada antes que estragasse. A luz tinha voltado, no tempo das crianÃ§as grandes, e feito desaparecer os medos do que se esconde nas trevas do que nÃ£o compreendemos.
TrÃªs dias depois, continuamos mais ou menos Ã s escuras quanto Ã s causas do incidente, mas nÃ£o percamos a esperanÃ§a: algo ficou jÃ¡ completamente claro. Sim, hÃ¡ mesmo uma luz que nunca se apaga â€“ e chama-se demagogia.
Em plena campanha eleitoral, quase nÃ£o houve quem nÃ£o tentasse capitalizar votos com o evento, com a novidade de, ao contrÃ¡rio do que era costume, o terem feito tÃ£o descaradamente quanto puderam. O governo gabou-se de ter posto o paÃ­s a funcionar em apenas â€“ apenas â€“ 11 horas; os dois maiores partidos da oposiÃ§Ã£o comportaram-se como dignos representantes de uma das mais lusitanas maneiras de ser: nÃ£o fizeram nada, mas passariam o dia a dizer como Ã© que se faz. Nada, todavia, bate o comportamento da esquerda em geral e de alguma mais extrema em particular: reclamou a â€œsoberania energÃ©ticaâ€ para Portugal. Soberania, a esquerda.
Valeu a pena a luz voltar sÃ³ para podermos ver e ouvir isto. Ã‰ que nÃ£o Ã© sÃ³ um tiro completamente demagÃ³gico e ao lado da questÃ£o, jÃ¡ que todos os especialistas explicaram que tal coisa Ã© completamente impossÃ­vel a um paÃ­s pequeno e perifÃ©rico como Portugal; Ã© a contradiÃ§Ã£o Ã³bvia que isso significaria. Ou a esquerda que defende, e bem, a descarbonizaÃ§Ã£o da economia, acha que a independÃªncia energÃ©tica se alcanÃ§aria como? Com petrÃ³leo, carvÃ£o, gÃ¡s natural ou nuclear? Ã‰ escolher. Para jÃ¡ nÃ£o falar do aumento que representaria na factura para o consumidor. Ou de quanto terÃ­amos de acrescentar com a renacionalizaÃ§Ã£o da REN, sacrificada Ã s privatizaÃ§Ãµes â€“ nunca esquecer â€“ vÃ­tima das maravilhas econÃ³micas da era SÃ³crates â€“ e como se o facto de a rede ser pÃºblica resolvesse o que quer que seja (em Espanha, por exemplo, onde o problema comeÃ§ou, Ã© pÃºblica).
Em suma: a esquerda quer um paÃ­s capaz de ser autossuficiente energeticamente, sÃ³ com renovÃ¡veis (cuja instabilidade natural parece cada vez mais ter estado na origem de todo o problema) e mais barata para o consumidor. Perto disto, ter sol na eira e chuva no nabal Ã© uma brincadeira de crianÃ§as.
Se houve beleza no dia? Sim, amigo leitor, tambÃ©m eu apreciei o momentÃ¢neo regresso Ã  magia do velho transÃ­stor ou o silÃªncio dos vÃ­deos em scroll nos rudes telemÃ³veis dos outros. Mas a grande liÃ§Ã£o que aprendemos no 28 de Abril de 2025 foi esta: no dia em que conseguirmos transformar demagogia em kilowatts, camaradas, os nossos polÃ­ticos vÃ£o iluminar o mundo.

author: Get News
title: Emery Buxtonâ€™s New Historical Novel Series Delivers Immersive Insight into Middle Eastern Theater of World War I | User | theeveningleader.com
text:
Renowned author Emery Buxton presents an extraordinary journey into the heart of World War I in his three-part historical novel series Reporting a War . [The series begins with Volume I: The Changing Landscape , offering a rich tapestry of the Middle East on the eve of war. The remaining two volume, focus on the decline of the Ottoman Empire and the emergence of British colonialism during the war.]. The series delivers an immersive and deeply engaging narrative that combines history with human stories and war journalism.
A Profound Exploration of Conflict and Change
In [the three volume series] readers are taken on a journey through the complex events and transformations of the Middle Eastern theater during World War I. The novel explores the interactions and conflicts between the Ottoman Empire and colonial powers, highlighting geopolitical dynamics and the struggles of various ethnic and religious groups. Through the eyes of war correspondents, readers gain insight into the experiences of soldiers and civilians, as well as the challenges and dangers faced by those reporting from the front lines.
Key Themes and Insights
Historical Context : The series provides a comprehensive view of the major events and circumstances surrounding the Middle Eastern theater of World War I. Cultural and Ethnic Awareness : Buxton's meticulous research brings to life the diverse cultures and identities within the Ottoman Empire, offering readers a deeper understanding of the region's complexities. Ethical and Moral Reflection : Through the lens of the international correspondents, the series explores the ethical dilemmas and challenges faced by journalists in times of conflict. Personal Relationships Amidst Turmoil : The novel weaves the personal relationship of the two correspondents into the broader narrative, adding depth and humanity to the wartime backdrop.
Volumes 2 and 3: Continuing the Journey
Following Volume I , Volume 2: The Impact of War and Volume 3: The Path to Resolution further explore the intricacies of World War I in the Middle East. These volumes delve into the Ottoman Empire's involvement in the war, strategic decisions, and the eventual collapse of the empire, culminating in the emergence of new political alignments and the rise of Arab nationalism.
For History Enthusiasts and Beyond
Reporting a War offers a rich blend of historical fiction and war literature, making it an essential read for history enthusiasts, students, academics, and fans of war fiction. The series addresses the emotional impact of war while providing readers with cultural insight and a deeper connection to history.
About the Author
The author was a specialist in international affairs and served in the U.S. State Department and at two major North American universities, researching and writing articles and studies on Islamic culture and its manifestations historically and in the modern era. See [H. Federspiel.] Sultans, Shamans and Saints: Islam and Muslims in Southeast Asia (available from Amazon Books) Writing under the pseudonym of Emery Buxton he published a series of four novels on the Korean War titled An Inconvenient War (available from Amazon Books and on Kindle). He resides in the beautiful hill country of Southeast Ohio where the people are warm and hospitable.
Book Name: The Changing Landscape: Volume I of the series Reporting a War

author: @travelnoire
title: How to Use Meditation Apps to Enhance Your Solo Travel Experience - Travel Noire
text:
Traveling solo can be a rewarding experienceâ€”it allows you to explore the world at your own pace, connect with yourself, and break away from daily routines. And in a fast-paced world full of too much noise (from both internal and external influences), there is a silence that comes from stepping into a new environment. But solo travel can also bring challenges like stress, homesickness, and fatigue. This is where meditation apps turn into a travel companion. By incorporating mindfulness practices into your journey, you can mitigate your changing emotional states for a more enriching and balanced adventure.
Why Meditation Apps Are Perfect for Solo Travel
Meditation apps are designed to bring calm and focus into your life, making them perfect for travel, for those new situations and environments we arenâ€™t always familiar with. Whether youâ€™re navigating a bustling city, adjusting to a new time zone, or simply unwinding after a long day, these apps provide the tools you need for relaxation and clarity. Beyond stress relief, meditation apps help solo travelers stay present, mindful, and in tune with their surroundings.
Benefits of Using Meditation Apps During Travel
Among the many benefits that come from taking a few minutes out of your day to focus on yourself, eliminating stress is a major incentive. Meditation apps help reduce stress caused by delays, language barriers, or crowded attractions through guided sessions specifically designed to promote calmness and relaxation. Apps like Headspace or Calm should be considered.
If you struggle sleeping in a new environment, sleep-focused meditation sessions from apps such as Insight Timer or Breethe can help you unwind and rest deeply, ensuring you wake up refreshed. Mindfulness exercises provided by these apps also allow you to stay grounded and presentâ€”whether admiring a sunrise or forming connections with locals, managing all that inward noise goes a long way with staying focused. Additionally, long travel days or decision fatigue can affect mental clarity, but apps like Simple Habit offer quick meditations to sharpen your focus and keep your mind clear in just minutes.
How to Incorporate Meditation Apps Into Your Solo Travel Routine
Start your mornings with a quick 5â€“10 minute guided meditation to set a positive tone for the day. Apps like Calm feature â€œMorning Focusâ€ sessions that mentally prepare you for the adventures ahead. During long flights, bus rides, or train journeys, practice mindful breathing to stay calm and relaxed. Apps like Insight Timer provide free breathing exercises that are perfect for these moments. After a full day of exploring, unwind with bedtime stories or sleep meditations from apps like Headspace.
These sessions help you reflect on your day and drift off peacefully. For remote destinations without Wi-Fi, apps such as Breethe and Ten Percent Happier allow you to download meditations offline. For those scenic spots, feel free to connect with nature by using meditations inspired by the environment. Calm also offers soundscapes and nature-themed meditations, such as ocean waves or forest ambiance, to deepen your sense of tranquility.
Top Meditation Apps for Solo Travelers
Headspace: Known for its user-friendly interface, Headspace offers meditations for travel anxiety, sleep, and mindfulness.
Calm: This app features a mix of guided meditations, soothing music, and nature sounds, making it ideal for solo adventurers.
Insight Timer: A free app with an extensive library of meditations, including sessions for travel stress and grounding techniques.
Breethe: Offers offline meditations, travel-focused sessions, and even short courses on overcoming jet lag.
Simple Habit: With quick meditations tailored for busy schedules, Simple Habit is perfect for solo travelers on the move.
Tips for Making Meditation a Habit During Travel
- Set a Reminder: Use the appâ€™s reminder feature to stay consistent with your practice.
- Keep It Short: Start with short sessions (3â€“5 minutes) and gradually increase as you get comfortable.
- Experiment With Different Features: Explore guided meditations, soundscapes, or breathing exercises to find what works best for you.
- Integrate With Your Activities: Meditate while sitting by the beach, hiking, or enjoying a quiet moment at a cafÃ©.
Closing Reflections on Solo Travel and Meditation
Solo travel is an opportunity for self-discovery, and meditation apps can be your guide along the way. By incorporating mindfulness practices, youâ€™ll feel more balanced, centered, and open to the experiences that await you. Download a meditation app, pack your bags, and plan your solo adventure today!

author: JT
title: Jordanians rally in solidarity with Gazans
text:
AMMAN â€” Jordanians took to the streets across the Kingdom on Friday to express solidarity with the Palestinian people in Gaza and condemn the violations committed by the Israeli occupation forces against innocent civilians in the Gaza Strip
The participants in the marches called on Arab countries and human rights organisations around the world to intervene and stand against the aggression on the besieged Strip, the Jordan News Agency, Petra, reported.
They also urged the international community, the UN Security Council, and relevant international organisations to shoulder their responsibilities to stop the aggression, which constitutes a violation of humanitarian laws and a blatant attack on innocent civilians.
The participants praised the steadfastness of the people of Gaza and Palestine in facing the genocide, condemning the international silence that ignores the ongoing massacres committed by Israel against innocent Palestinian civilians, and the double standards policy in dealing with the Israeli war on Gaza and its consequences.
The participants in the marches praised the role played by Jordan, under the leadership of His Majesty King Abdullah, in supporting and advocating for the people of Gaza and the West Bank to stop the aggression and prevent Israeli attacks and practices against the Palestinian people, and to defend the Palestinian cause.
